headline: Preterm babies may have behavioural, learning problems -Study
summarized_story:
Angela OnwuzooA new study has indicated that preterm babies born before 37 weeks of pregnancy are at risk of developmental challenges that can affect their behaviour and ability to learn.
The researchers stated that though survival of preterm babies has increased worldwide, children born early often have developmental issues.
According to the World Health Organisation, preterm is defined as babies born alive before 37 weeks of pregnancy are completed.
Dr. Airhumwunde noted that gestational age and delivery were the two major factors that determine the survival of preterm babies.
The gynaecologist pointed out that babies born below 34 weeks have a poor survival rate, while babies delivered above 34 weeks have up to 80 percent survival rate.

headline: FRENCH OPEN: Nadal sinks Schwartzman to reach semi-finals
summarized_story:

summarized_story:

headline: Police arrest IPOB/ESN native doctor in Imo
summarized_story:
The Tactical teams of the Imo state Police Command has arrested a notorious native doctor who prepares charms for members of the proscribed Indigenous people of Biafra and eight others.
The suspect confessed to be a member of IPOB/ESN, and made useful statements to the Police as regards to the recent attacks on Police stations as well as the residence of Governor Hope Uzodinma.
However, two (2) out of the nine arrested in the hideout, CHINEDU NWAKAIRE aka ONE DOOR and UZOAMAKA UGOANYANWU (their native Doctor) were identified to be part of the hoodlums that attacked the private residence of Gov.
Hope Uzodinma and also some Police stations as well.

headline: NECO Will Not Extend Registration For 2021 SSCE Internal Candidates – Sani
summarized_story:
The Head of Information and Public Relations Division,Azeez Sani, has revealed that the National Examinations Council (NECO) will not extend the registration period for internal candidates for the 2021 Senior School Certificate Examination (SSCE).
Mr. Sani stated in a statement on Wednesday that the registration period, which began on March 31st, will end on Friday, June 25th, 2021, and will not be extended.
According to him, this will enable efficient and effective planning for the examination logistics required for the smooth conduct of the 2021 SSCE internal candidates.
“State Ministries of Education, Commandants, Principals, Proprietors, and other relevant stakeholders are enjoined to take note of the closing date and ensure timely completion of their candidates’ registration.
Advertisement“The Council assures all stakeholders of its resolve to have seamless conduct of the 2021 SSCE”, he further stated.

headline: US to Share 500 Million Covid Vaccines Through COVAX for Africa, Others
summarized_story:
The US will buy 500 million more doses of the Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine to share through the global COVAX alliance for donation to 92 lower income countries and the African Union over the next year, a person familiar with the matter said Wednesday.
Two hundred million doses — enough to fully protect 100 million people — would be shared this year, with the balance to be donated in the first half of 2022, the person said.
The U.S. has faced mounting pressure to outline its global vaccine sharing plan.
Overall, the White House has announced plans to share 80 million doses globally by the end of June, most through COVAX.

headline: Twitter, Other ICT Players Contributed 14.91% to Nigeria’s GDP, Civil Society Group Reminds FG
summarized_story:
A leading civil society organization, Centre for Social Justice (CSJ) has reminded the federal government that Twitter and other social media platforms belong to the Information Communications sector which contributed 14.9 per cent to the 2021 first quarter (Q1) gross domestic product (GDP).
CSJ, which expressed regret over the recent ban on the micro-blogging site by the federal government called for an immediate reversal of the action.
“The Information and Communications sector is composed of the four activities of Telecommunications and Information Services; Publishing; Motion Picture, Sound Recording and Music Production; and Broadcasting.
It observed that the fact that Nigeria is just struggling to exit recession even compounds the scenario.
It noted that the ban on Twitter at a time of great economic and social crisis has so many downsides without any evident upside.

headline: Nigeria: I’d Rather Die Than Pay Ransom to Kidnappers, Says Kaduna Governor El-Rufai’s Wife
summarized_story:
One of the wives of Governor Nasir El-Rufai of Kaduna state, Hajiya Asia El-Rufai, has declared that she would rather die than ransom be paid to kidnappers if she gets abducted.

headline: Nigeria: Judicial Workers Suspend Two-month Long Strike
summarized_story:
The Judiciary Staff Union of Nigeria (JUSUN) has called off its two-month long strike with effect from 14th June, 2021 after a prolonged National Eexecutive Council (NEC) meeting.
The National Judicial Council (NJC) had, at a meeting on Tuesday with JUSUN leaders and the Chief Justice of Nigeria (CJN), Justice Ibrahim Muhammad, urged the striking court workers to put an end to the industrial action in the interest of the country and the suffering court users.
Members of the union have been on strike since April 6, 2021 in agitation for the financial independence of the various state judiciaries.
A subsequent Executive Order was issued by the Nigerian President Muhammadu Buhari for the “Implementation of financial Autonomy of States Legislature and State Judiciary” on 20th May 2020.
However, some state governors have failed to implement this fundamental provision of the Law.
